field.name: Content standard - science - National Science Education Standards (NSES)
field.definition: a vision of a scientifically literate populace by outlining what students need to know, understand, and be able to do to be scientifically literate at different grade levels

levelAndDeftn.levelDeftn: the name of the group or organization responsible for the controlled vocabulary
the set of grade levels to which the standard applies

levelTermsAndDeftns.levelTermAndDeftn: kindergarten, first grade, second grade, third grade and fourth grade
fifth grade, sixth grade, seventh grade and eighth grade
high school grades nine, ten, eleven and twelve

levelAndDeftn.levelDeftn: a named and lettered level of achievement to which learners are expected to aspire

Content Standard B Physical Science Standards
Content Standard C Life Science Standards
Content Standard D Earth and Space Science Standards
Content Standard E Science and Technology Standards
Content Standard F Science in Personal and Social Perspectives Standards
Content Standard G History and Nature of Science Standards

levelAndDeftn.levelDeftn: the high-level topic area addressed by the standard; see the allowed combination of terms below; the concept part of the term is the phrase after the last colon

dos.practice: Choosing a standard signifies that the content of the resource supports student learning and attainment of the abilities articulated in the standard.
Use standards with materials intended for student learning.
Catalogers with experience and familiarity with standards may evaluate the standards identified by resource creators in the resource for appropriateness and completeness.
If catalogers do not have experience and familiarity with standards but the resource has standards associated with, catalogers may include the standards indicated by the resource creator.
Catalogers with experience and familiarity with standards may evaluate a resource to identify appropriate standards.
Use standards sparingly with reference materials, portal resources or other resources where student interaction with the resource is low or passive.

donts.practice: Catalogers who do not have experience and familiarity with standards, should not complete this field.

Do not create a compiled list of standards addressed by a collection of resources. For example, do not create a long list of standards for an overarching resource that includes individual lesson plans, activities or modules that support individual standards. Describe each lesson plan, activity or module, etc. individually and associate the standards directly.
Do not choose every standard for a resource. Most resources only support a few standards really well.

otherPractice.header: The resource has existing standards. Do this:
otherPractice.practice: When standards are identified by the resource creator and presented in the resource, capture this information when it meets the other criteria described by these best practices.

otherPractice.header: Does an entire resource need to support the standard?
otherPractice.practice: A resource need not cover the entire scope of a standard for the association to be made but the resource content should clearly fall within the bounds of the standard. Some of the standards are broad in scope. Therefore, it is not expected that single resources, like lesson plans, activities or modules, support the entirety of a standard.

practice.link1: NSES:9-12:Content Standard A:Science as Inquiry Standards:Abilities necessary to do scientific inquiry

otherPractice.practice: NSES:9-12:Content Standard A:Science as Inquiry Standards:Abilities necessary to do scientific inquiry is supported in Stratospheric Ozone.

practice.link1: NCGE:Physical Systems:The physical processes that shape the patterns of Earth's surface

otherPractice.practice: NCGE:Physical Systems:The physical processes that shape the patterns of Earth's surface is supported in Introduction to Waves.

practice.link1: NCGE:The World in Spatial Terms:How to use maps and other geographic representations, tools, and technologies to acquire, process, and report information
practice.link2: Exploring Earthquakes in Space and Time Through the Internet and a Geographic Information System

otherPractice.practice: NCGE:The World in Spatial Terms:How to use maps and other geographic representations, tools, and technologies to acquire, process, and report information is supported in Exploring Earthquakes in Space and Time Through the Internet and a Geographic Information System.
The National Council for Geographic Education standards are designed to emphasize the knowledge skills of a geographically informed person.
Choose appropriate geography standards from the list.
The National Science Education Standards (NSES) are designed to emphasize interacting with the science content, the processes of science, inquiry and decision-making skills.
Choose appropriate science standards from the list.
See the fourth level of the standard which includes specific abilities.
See the fourth level of the standard which includes specific abilities.
See the fourth level of the standard which includes specific abilities.

If the resource indicates other standards such as the Benchmarks for Science Literacy (by the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS), the Principles and Standards for School Mathematics by the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics (NCTM) or the National Educational Technology Standards by International Society for Technology in Education (ISTE) etc., enter this information in the description - educational field, citing the authorizing body and source for the standard.

documentation.obligation: required metadata if parent tag is present
documentation.example: NSES:K-4:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science Standards:Properties of earth materials
